bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, May 25, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant James Bradley, May 25, 1728, to inform him of tobacco he is sending on one of Bradley's ships, and to report that the colony is sending John Randolph to Lodnon to work for the repeal of the prohibition on the production of stemmed tobacco.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, May 25, 1728

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
May the 25th: 1728
Mr. James Bradley

div1.p:
This is to own the receipt of Several Lettrs
from you this year I do not at present remember to have
writ you any answer nor shall I say much now Capt Trice
hath been with me and hath Some of my Tobbo on Board
whether he [illegible] will want any more of whether I shall have
any more for him I dont yet know

We are in the great design of getting a repeal
of the clause in the Act of Parliamt: prohibiting the Steming
of Tobbo repealed The Council & Burgesses have addressed
his Majty and made Application to the parliamt: about it
Mr. John Randolph one of our Eminentest Lawyers
is coming home as the Countreys Agent to Solicite the
Affair our Great hopes are that all the Merchts: both the
London [illegible] & outports & the North Brittains will be Strongly
our friends in joyning their Interst in getting this
grievous restraint taken of to the releif of the Trade in
General as to well as to & the poor makers of Tobbo in particular the
many reasons we have to Urge to prove it will be no
Detriment to the Crown as well as the great benefit
that will Accrue to the Mercht and to the planter our Agent
is fully Instructed in, and will much better Illustrate [illegible]
then I can; I shall only wish you will be one of those if
that will show your self forward in heartily promoting
this good design I am
div1.closer:
Sir
Your most humble Servt
per Clack
Trice

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. His location, the county and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded draft.

[1] James Bradley was a London merchant with whom Carter dealt from at least 1723 until his death. As noted in his letter to Bradley of 1727 May 17, Bradley owned the Welcome, but little information about Bradley has been located.

[2] The 140 ton Welcome was owned by London merchant James Bradley to whom Carter would write about her on 1727 May 17. John Trice (Frice) was her captain, 1723-1728. (Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, 154r, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[3] Parliament had passed the act forbidding the importation of stemmed tobacco in 1722. Randolph would not leave for England until 1729; his mission would be successful. (Arthur Pierce Middleton. Tobacco Coast: A Maritime History of the Chesapeake Bay in the Colonial Era. [Newport News, VA: Mariners' Museum, 1953.] p. 116.)
[5] No information has been located on Captain Clack who is mentioned in several of Carter's letters of this period.
